Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Development of a Stable Transformation System in the Red Alga Porphyra Umbilicalis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Bacteria are critical to the normal development of multicellular organisms, including algae, and bacteria may help algae survive environmental stresses, but these associations remain poorly understood. The red alga Porphyra umbilicalis ('laver') experiences intertidal stresses that include high temperature, high light, and desiccation, but the alga recovers quickly when submerged again at high tide. Laver is currently the subject of an extensive bacterial microbiome study, and now has a fully-sequenced genome, making it an ideal candidate for investigations of how bacterial associations confer stress tolerance on a molecular level. One way to enable these investigations is to create a system to manipulate laver?s genes, i.e. stable genetic transformation. This work is proposed in collaboration with Dr. Hiroyuki Mizuta and Dr. Toshiki Uji of Hokkaido University, Japan. Dr. Uji is a leading expert on genetic transformation in red algae, and he and his colleagues recently developed a stable transformation system for nori (Pyropia yezoensis), a Pacific cousin of laver. A stable transformation system will allow research to be conducted on stress responses in laver, including possible effects of the microbiome, and will provide an invaluable tool for other scientific studies based on the Porphyra genome.

The primary goal of this work is to establish the first stable transformation system in P. umbilicalis. Plasmids containing a heat shock factor (HSF) gene and a selectable marker (hygromycin B resistance) will be inserted via particle bombardment into both P. umbilicalis and P. yezoensis. Germination and development of transformed protoplasts or neutral spores will be evaluated, and transformants of both species will be subjected to comparative heat shock treatments and their HSF expression analyzed. This comparison is useful because P. umbilicalis and P. yezoensis are related members of one of the oldest eukaryotic groups (Bangiophyceae), and they are both economically and culturally important algae.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The marine red alga Porphyra umbilicalis experiences extreme abiotic stress while growing along rocky intertidal zones in northern New England. Temperature flux, light flux, and desiccation are daily stressors, making P. ubmilicalis an important model organism for studying stress responses in algae. This alga is closely related to Pyropia yezoensis (nori), one of the most economically and culturally important seaweeds in the world. The importance of P. yezoensis and its status as a model organism prompted researchers in Japan to develop protocols for stable genetic transformation of this alga using biolistic particle bombardment. Stable genetic transformation involves inserting and incorporating a DNA construct of interest into the nuclear genome of an organism, making it a useful technique for understanding gene function.

Because development of a stable transformation system in P. yezoensis was successful, and because of the newly-available whole genome sequence for P. umbilicalis, a collaboration to create a stable genetic transformation system in P. umbilicalis was proposed. The major project goals were to establish parameters for stable genetic transformation of P. umbilicalis using methods developed for P. yezoensis, and to test this system by creating an overexpression model of the heat shock factor (HSF) gene in both algae and compare the resopnses. HSF genes govern many stress responses in the cell, making them ideal targets for elucidating the multiple stress-tolerance capabilities of P. umbilicalis. This collaboration was proposed as part of an East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) fellowship funded by NSF and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

 

During the fellowship period, important progress was made towards developing a transformation system in P. umbilicalis.  A set of bombardment condtions were also established, though transformation efficiency remained low throughout these trials. One key discovery was that the surface of P. umbilicalis was more resistant to particle penetration than that of P. yezoensis. Additional treatments with sulfatase and 1-aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylic acid (ACC) slightly increased the number oftransformed regions, but levels remained low. Upon returning to the US, the student performed additional particle bombardments on clusters of exposed asexual "neutral" spores. The use of exposed spores further increased transformation success, indicating that improved exposure of P. umbilicalis cells is needed to obtain higher transformation efficiency.  The student was also able to demonstrate that the antibiotic selectable marker used by the host researchers to separate transformed P. yezoensis cells could be used in P. umbilicalis, providing a vital tool for use in later transformation attempts. Due to unclear qPCR results and low expression levels indicated by RT-PCR, further investigation of the HSF gene and its expression patterns is needed before a HSF overexpression assay can be conducted.

Overall, the results from this fellowship have made significant contributions to the fields of macroalgal genetic transformation and algal genomics research.  The results from particle bombardment and antibiotic trials have laid the foundation for further development of stable genetic transformation in this alga, and provided scientists with an interest in the P. umbilicalis genome a starting point for pursuing genetic transformation in this important model organism.
